questions.question: Arrange the following sites of ectopic pregnancy from the most common to the least common.
Which of the following factors maximally increases the risk of tubal pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Prior tubal surgery for ectopic pregnancy has the highest risk of tubal pregnancy among the givenoptions.Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy:• Prior ectopic pregnancy• Prior tubal surgery for ectopic, recanalization of tube post-sterilization• Pelvic inflammatory disease - most common cause for ectopic pregnancy•Infertility• Artificial reproductive therapy• Endometriosis•Smoking• Maternal age >40 years•Contraceptive methods - intrauterine device, progesterone-only pills

questions.question: The fall in which of the following hormone/s leads to endometrial sloughing in ectopicgestation?
questions.explanation: 338Endometrial sloughing in ectopic gestation is due to the fall in the levels of progesterone and hCG.During normal pregnancy, endometrium is maintained by the high levels of hCG andprogesterone. In ectopic pregnancy, a fall in the levels of these hormones will cause endometrialsloughing and uterine bleeding. If the decidua is expelled as a single piece through the cervix, it iscalled a decidual cast.

questions.question: Which type of tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage?
questions.explanation: Interstitial tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage i.e. at 12-16 weeks. This is because pregnancyat this site is closer to the uterine myometrium which provides support as pregnancy progresses.Isthmic and ampullary pregnancies terminate by tubal rupture. However, isthmic pregnancyruptures earlier. Ampullary and infundibular pregnancy can terminate by tubal abortion as well.

questions.question: Which of the following clinical features is not seen in a patient with ruptured ectopicpregnancy?
questions.explanation: A shock index of >0.85 is seen in a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. There is massive bloodloss (SBP<110 mmHg) sometimes leading to shock.The shock index is calculated as HR/systolic BP.Option A: Sub-diaphragmatic blood irritates the phrenic nerve. This causes a referred pain at theshoulder tip. This is called as Danforth sign.Option B: The expulsion of decidua in a single piece through the cervix is called a decidual cast.This is due to the fall in the levels of ẞ hCG and progesterone.Option C: Vertigo and syncope are due to reflex vasomotor disturbances due to peritonealirritation from hemoperitoneum.ConditionRange of shock indexNormal value of shock index(non-pregnant)0.5-0.7Normal value of shock indexin pregnancy (i.e) obstetricalshock indexSignificant or massive blood 1OSS0.7-0.80.9 - 1.1

questions.question: A woman presented with complaints of amenorrhoea for 6 weeks and a history of priorectopic pregnancy. Serial serum beta hCG levels were estimated in her. Which of thefollowing findings will increase the suspicion of ectopic gestation in her?

options.A: Low levels with prolonged doubling time
options.B: High levels with decreased doubling time

questions.explanation: Low levels of ẞ hCG and prolonged doubling time increase the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy.339Urine pregnancy test is very sensitive and found positive in most ectopic pregnancies. Hence,serial serum ẞ hCG levels are estimated to detect ectopic pregnancy. In early normal pregnancy,the doubling time of ẞ hCG concentrations in plasma is 1.4 to 2 days.

questions.question: A patient presented with 6 weeks of amenorrhoea and a positive UPT. TVS revealed a tubalectopic pregnancy. Which of the following findings can be usually picked up on colourDoppler?

options.A: Enhanced blood flow pattern in the uterine artery

questions.explanation: Ring of fire pattern is seen on color doppler in a tubal ectopic pregnancy. This is due to placentalblood flow in the tubal pregnancy.This finding may also be seen in corpus luteum cysts but the wall is less echogenic compared totubal ectopic.Option A: There is an enhanced blood flow pattern outside the uterine cavity in case of ectopicpregnancy.GERt Adnexa0-10L 0.56 cmOption B: Arias-Stella reaction/phenomenon is a histological finding. It is an atypical endometrialchange due to the action of progesterone on the endometrial tissue seen in normal, ectopic, andmolar pregnancies.On histology, there are:large cells with abundant eosinophilic or vacuolated cytoplasm⚫ nuclear enlargement•• hyperchromasia340Option D: Whirlpool sign refers to the twisted ovarian pedicle seen on USG of ovarian torsion.

questions.question: 333A pregnant woman came for routine antenatal USG. Which of the following features issuggestive of a pseudogestational sac?
questions.explanation: Central location is a feature of the pseudogestational sac seen in ectopic pregnancies.Pseudogestational sac is a collection of fluid between the endometrial layers, surrounded by athick decidua. Its presence increases the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy.Differences between pseudogestational sac and true gestational sac:FeatureLocation within the endometrial cavityPseudogestational saTrue gestational saCCCentralEccentricShapeUsually ovoidUsually roundFetal and yolk sac polesAbsentPresentDouble ring signAbsentSeenIntradecidual signAbsentSeen

questions.question: A patient with suspected tubal pregnancy underwent transvaginal ultrasound which wasinconclusive. What is the next step of management?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, the next step would be to confirm the tubal ectopic by measuring serum ßhCG. This can be used to differentiate tubal ectopic pregnancy from missed abortion and earlyintrauterine pregnancy.341If the level is ≥2000 IU/L, ectopic pregnancy is suspected. If the level is <1500 IU/L, a repeatserum ẞ hCG is taken after 48 hours. If the levels are:•• Doubled early intrauterine pregnancy-• Decreased - abortion• Increased but less than doubled value ectopic pregnancyInvestigations for ectopic pregnancy:-⚫ Serum ẞ hCG - lower levels compared to normal pregnancy, prolonged doubling time•• Transvaginal ultrasound - empty uterine cavity, fluid in pouch of Douglas, adnexal mass• Colour Doppler ring of fire pattern•Laparoscopy-• Dilatation and curettage - decidua identified without villi• Serum progesterone• CuldocentesisDiagnostic laparoscopy may be done when the diagnosis is still uncertain after serial ẞ-hCGmonitoring and repeat ultrasonography. In high-risk situations, such as a history of previousectopic pregnancy, earlier diagnostic laparoscopy is considered.Management ofsuspected ectopic pregnancyHemodynamicallystable+UPTHemodynamicallyunstableARROTVUSResuscitationBedside US & FAST(suspect ruptured ectopic)IUPEctopichCGdoublesNondiagnostichCG levels <1500Repeat hCG levels in 48-72 hrsOpen Surgical MxhCG doeshCG plateausnot doubleor decreasesSuggests IUPRepeat TVUSSuggests Ectopic,Repeat TVUSFailed pregnancy.Follow closelyMARROW

questions.question: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with unruptured ectopic gestation. Which of the following isnot an indication for expectant management in this patient?

options.A: Initial serum beta hCG level of 200 mIU/mL

questions.explanation: A gestational sac size of <4 cm is an indication of expectant management.Expectant management is done only in the case of unruptured tubal pregnancy. In this,observation is done till there is spontaneous resolution. It can be done but is not preferred due toprolonged follow-up and uncertainty in resolution.The indications are:342• Initial serum ẞ hCG <1500 IU/L•Falling serum ẞ hCG levels•Gestational sac size <4 cm•No fetal cardiac activity on TVS• No evidence of rupture or bleeding on TVS

questions.question: A primigravida in her first trimester came for a routine ANC. USG findings revealed an emptyuterine cavity. Serum beta hCG was measured and was found to be 1700 IU/mL. All of thefollowing drugs can be used in managing this patient except:
questions.explanation: Oxytocin is not used in the management of unruptured ectopic pregnancy.Indications for medical management of unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy:• Hemodynamically stable patient••Serum ẞ hCG <5000 IU/LTubal diameter <4 cmNo fetal cardiac activity• No intra-abdominal haemorrhageMedical management of unruptured tubal ectopic:• Direct local therapy (laparoscopy or USG guidance) -•Methotrexate•• Potassium chloride•Actinomycin• Hyperosmolar glucose• PGF2°•Systemic therapy - single dose of methotrexate 50 mg/m2 IMFollow-up after medical management is done by measuring the decline in serial serum ẞ hCG.

questions.question: A patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy is planned for medical management withmethotrexate. What is the multi-dose protocol for this drug?
questions.explanation: In the multi-dose protocol, methotrexate is given at a dose of 1 mg/kg as an IM injectionon alternate days 1, 3, 5, and 7.This regimen is continued on alternating days until the hCG level drops by 15% over two days. Upto 4 doses may be given. Along with this, leucovorin rescue (folinic acid) is given at 0.1 mg/kg after24 hrs (on days 2, 4, 6, and 8) to buffer the side effects of methotrexate.Note: If the decline is ≥15%, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L.343MTX ProtocolDoseRegimenhCG measurementTreatment successWhen to administer additional doseMulti-dose regimen1 mg/kg(+ 0.1 mg/kg LEU)Alternate daily dosesDays 0, 1, 3, 5, 7hCG declines >15%from theprevious value2nd, 3rdor 4thdose to be given if hCG does not decline 15% from the previous value. Maximum 4 dosesSingle-dose regimen50 mg/m2(Body surface area)Day oDays 0, 4, 7hCG declines >15%betweenDay 4 and 7Second dose onDay 7if hCG does not decline 15%

questions.question: Which of the following must be avoided by a patient with tubal pregnancy on methotrexate?
questions.explanation: Sunlight exposure, sexual intercourse and NSAIDs must be avoided when patients are onmethotrexate therapy.The following should be avoided when methotrexate therapy has been initiated for the treatmentof ectopic gestation:•• Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs - can cause reduced renal blood flow and delay drugexcretion• Alcohol - can predispose to concurrent hepatic enzyme elevation.Sunlight may provoke methotrexate-related dermatitis• Sexual intercourse can rupture the ectopic pregnancy•-Phenytoin, tetracyclines, salicylates, and sulfonamides - can increase serum methotrexate levels

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state with complaints ofbleeding PV associated with abdominal pain and a history of amenorrhoea for 8 weeks. Onexamination, BP was 90/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm, and UPT was positive. What is the nextstep of management?

options.B: Resuscitation and emergency laparotomySuction and evacuationd) FAST followed by laparoscopic salpingectomyQuestion 15:Match the following criteria used for the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy:a) 1-A, 2-C, 3-Bb) 2-B, 3-A, 4-C335

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ruptured ectopic pregnancy which must beimmediately managed with simultaneous resuscitation and laparotomy. On laparotomy,salpingectomy is the definitive surgery.•Diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is made based on clinical features:• Amenorrhoea for 6-8 weeks followed by bleeding PV•Abdominal pain• Hemodynamically unstable• Urine pregnancy test - positiveSurgical treatment of ectopic pregnancy includes salpingectomy or salpingostomy, performedeither through laparoscopy or laparotomy.344Management of suspected ruptured ectopic pregnancy consists of initial resuscitation andstabilization, followed by point-of-care ultrasound (FAST) to identify intraperitoneal free fluid andsurgical exploration.Laparotomy is done for hemodynamically unstable patients with ruptured ectopic pregnancies.Salpingectomy is the treatment of choice and is done with preservation of the ipsilateral ovary andits vascular supply.For patients wishing to preserve future fertility, if the contralateral fallopian tube is damaged,salpingostomy is preferred. However, salpingostomy may result in inadequate evacuation of theproducts of conception and a recurrence of symptoms. Therefore, after a patient undergoessalpingostomy, it is important check the ẞ-hCG level on a weekly basis to ensure that it reacheszero.The image given below shows a laparoscopic visualization of a tubal pregnancy.Management ofsuspected ectopic pregnancy+UPTHemodynamicallystableTVUSIUPEctopichCGdoublesHemodynamicallyunstableRROResuscitationBedside US & FAST(suspect ruptured ectopic)NondiagnostichCG levels <1500Repeat hCG levels in 48-72 hrsOpen Surgical MxhCG doesnot doublehCG plateausor decreasesSuggests IUPRepeat TVUSSuggests Ectopic,Repeat TVUSFailed pregnancy.Follow closelyMARROW345

questions.question: An O-ve primigravida underwent surgery for ectopic pregnancy at 13 weeks of gestation.What will be the dose of anti-D immunoglobulin to be given to her?
questions.explanation: Anti-D is given at a dose of 300 µg intramuscularly for alloimmunization after surgicalmanagement of ectopic pregnancy.The dose of anti-D in a surgically treated case of ectopic is 50 µg if gestation <12 weeks. If thegestation is >12 weeks, 300 μg of anti-D is given intramuscularly.Anti-D is not given when the ectopic is treated with medical methods.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female patient (G2POA1) with a history of FSH therapy and in vitro fertilizationpresented with lower abdominal pain, vomiting, and vaginal discharge. On examination, shewas hemodynamically stable. Transvaginal ultrasound showed a viable intrauterinepregnancy of 8 weeks associated with a heterogeneous right adnexal mass showing a positivebagel sign. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of heterotopic pregnancy. Surgery is the ideal treatmentin heterotopic pregnancy.A normal uterine pregnancy co-existing with an extrauterine (ectopic) pregnancy is termed aheterotopic pregnancy. Although heterotopic pregnancy can occur spontaneously, it is more likelyafter ART and ovulation induction.Tubal ring sign also referred to as bagel sign is one of the ultrasound signs of a tubal ectopic. Itcomprises an echogenic ring that surrounds an unruptured ectopic pregnancy.USG image showing bagel sign or tubal ring sign:346GestationalsacHyperechoicringMethotrexate is not to be given as it harms even the normal intrauterine fetus. Althoughpotassium chloride may be injected into the sac of the ectopic, the safer method would be surgeryto remove the ectopic.

questions.question: Methotrexate was administered to a patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy. At whatserum beta hCG levels will this drug be most effective?
questions.explanation: Methotrexate is most effective when given at ẞ hCG levels are <5000 IU/L.Methotrexate is given at a dose of 50 mg/m2 of body surface area. Monitoring is done bymeasuring ẞ hCG levels on days 4 and 7. If the decline is ≥15% of the initial value, the patient isfollowed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L. If the decline is <15%, a 2nd dose ofmethotrexate is given on day 7.

questions.question: 336Studdiford's criteria is used for the diagnosis of
questions.explanation: Studdiford's criteria is used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy.Primary abdominal pregnancy is the rarest type of ectopic gestation. The conceptus implants onthe peritoneal surface of the abdomen.Studdiford's criteria:• The presence of normal bilateral tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past pregnancy.• No evidence of a uteroperitoneal fistula.• The presence of pregnancy, related exclusively to the peritoneal surface, early enough toeliminate the possibility of secondary implantationCriteria used in the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy are:• Cervical pregnancy: Paalman and McElin (clinical criteria); Rubin's criteria (histological criteria)347• Ovarian pregnancy: Spiegelberg's criteria.348
